page.title: 14ECOLOGY IN WESTFIELD
page.content: Mr and Mrs Keele have to cut down the coarse grass and plants annually so that the other rare plants can grow. They do this work in the autumn and winter with the help of local conservationists. Mrs Keele thinks that the reserve is called Lolly Moor because it is low-lying moorland (low-lie = lolly). Lolly Moor Nature Reserve is open to the public and it is one of several sites controlled by the Norfolk Naturalists Trust who are fighting to maintain the natural fauna and wildlife of the region. To encourage young people to take an interest in conservation the mid-Norfolk branch of the Naturalists Trust has formed a local branch of Watch which also helps to look after the reserve.
